message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Dextromethorphan is known to cause constipation as a common side effect. Diphenhydramine and Loratadine can cause dry mouth, but not constipation. Guaifenesin can cause nausea and stomach discomfort, but not constipation.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Dextromethorphan can cause constipation. It is an ingredient in some over-the-counter cough and cold medicines.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Dextromethorphan is known to cause constipation as one of its side effects. It is important to note that constipation can also be a common side effect of opioids, which were not included as an option in this question.

We refer to the MedlinePlus drug information database for help. Dextromethorphan, a common ingredient in cough and cold medicines, can cause constipation as a side effect. Diphenhydramine and loratadine are antihistamines and do not typically cause constipation. Guaifenesin is an expectorant and also does not typically cause constipation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, Dextromethorphan is known to have the side effect of constipation. Diphenhydramine can cause drowsiness and dry mouth, but not constipation. Guaifenesin and Loratadine do not have constipation as a reported side effect.

Diphenhydramine, guaifenesin, and loratadine are not known to cause constipation as a common side effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only dextromethorphan has been known to cause constipation as a side effect. Diphenhydramine can cause dry mouth which may exacerbate constipation, but it is not a known cause of constipation itself. Guaifenesin and loratadine are not known to cause constipation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Only Dextromethorphan is known to cause constipation as a side effect. Diphenhydramine may cause dry mouth, but not constipation. Guaifenesin and Loratadine have no known association with constipation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, dextromethorphan is the most likely cause of constipation due to its anticholinergic effects, which can delay gastrointestinal motility. Diphenhydramine can also cause constipation, but it is less commonly associated with the symptom. Guaifenesin and loratadine are not known to cause constipation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Dextromethorphan is known to cause constipation as a side effect. Diphenhydramine can cause dry mouth which can contribute to constipation, but it is not a direct cause. Guaifenesin and Loratadine are not known to cause constipation as a side effect.
